summary: This is a detailed privilege log from a civil case (9:08-cv-80736-KAM) filed in Florida, listing documents withheld from discovery. It catalogs extensive investigative materials from the federal criminal investigation into Jeffrey Epstein, including grand jury materials, search warrants, financial records, victim/witness information, and attorney work product. The log reveals the scope of the 'Operation Leap Year' grand jury investigation and the preparation of an indictment against Epstein. This document is a detailed privilege log from a civil case (9:08-cv-80736-KAM) filed in 2013, listing and describing materials from the 2006-2009 federal investigation into Jeffrey Epstein. It catalogs evidence, grand jury materials, draft indictments, victim analyses, legal research, and correspondence, many of which are withheld under claims of work product, grand jury secrecy (Rule 6(e)), and investigative privilege. This document is a privilege log from a court filing (likely a Vaughn index) listing documents withheld from production in the Epstein case. It describes emails and letters between Department of Justice officials regarding the office-wide recusal of the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida from the Epstein investigation, and includes a memorandum summarizing the investigation. Attorney-client privilege and deliberative process privilege are asserted.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The central subject of the federal investigation codenamed 'Operation Leap Year.' The log references draft indictments, a non-prosecution agreement, and motions related to his case.

persons.name: Col. M. Gauger
persons.role: Palm Beach County Sheriff's Office Official
persons.context: Recipient of a July 3, 2008 email regarding Jeffrey Epstein's work release status from the Palm Beach County Sheriff's Office (PBSO).

persons.name: Wifredo Ferrer
persons.role: U.S. Attorney, Southern District of Florida
persons.context: Recipient of an email regarding the formal notice of office-wide recusal of the Southern District of Florida from the Epstein investigation. Also mentioned as the recipient of a letter from Paul Cassell.

persons.name: Robert O'Neill
persons.role: U.S. Attorney, Middle District of Florida
persons.context: Recipient of an email regarding the formal notice of office-wide recusal of the Southern District of Florida.

persons.name: Paul Cassell
persons.context: Author of a letter dated December 10, 2010, to U.S. Attorney Wifredo A. Ferrer, which was attached to emails seeking advice regarding office-wide recusal.

connections.description: Both are U.S. Attorneys (for Southern and Middle Districts of Florida, respectively) copied on the same official DOJ email regarding the recusal of the Southern District from the Epstein case.
Cassell sent a letter to Ferrer, which was later attached to internal DOJ emails discussing the office's recusal from the Epstein investigation.

events.title: Formal Notice of Office-Wide Recusal
events.description: Formal notice was issued regarding the office-wide recusal of the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida from the Epstein investigation.

keyFacts: The document is a privilege log from a 2013 civil case, cataloging materials from the federal criminal investigation (Operation Leap Year) into Jeffrey Epstein that were withheld from discovery.

The investigation involved a grand jury that issued at least 81 subpoenas (OLY-01 through OLY-81) targeting financial records, flight manifests, phone records, and corporate documents related to Epstein.

Prosecutors compiled extensive 'indictment preparation binders' containing victim/witness lists, sexual activity summaries, phone and flight record analyses, FBI 302s, and photographs for numerous Jane Does (at least #1-19).
Investigative targets included Epstein's corporations, banks (Colonial Bank, JP Morgan Chase, Washington Mutual, Capital One), Bear Stearns, FedEx, Dollar Rent-a-Car, and flight companies.

The log indicates the investigation sought information on 'past employees' and 'miscellaneous witnesses,' and prosecutors researched Epstein's past lawsuits and financial relationships with entities like the SEC.

The log reveals the existence of a detailed federal investigation codenamed 'Operation Leap Year,' which compiled extensive evidence including victim meta-analyses, phone records, flight logs, and draft indictments against Jeffrey Epstein from 2007-2009.

Prosecutors created detailed 'FBI Summary Charts' and victim-specific folders (Jane Doe #1-14, etc.) containing meta-analyses of phone, travel, and grand jury data for indictment preparation, indicating a systematic effort to build a case.

The log references the signed Non-Prosecution Agreement (NPA) from December 19, 2007, and a later 'Breach Memo' analyzing a potential breach of that agreement, highlighting the contested nature of the deal.
Multiple names of attorneys, AUSAs, and victims are redacted throughout the document, indicated by brackets or blank spaces, showing the sensitivity and ongoing privacy protections in the litigation.
The U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida underwent an office-wide recusal from the Jeffrey Epstein investigation, formalized in August 2011.
Internal DOJ emails and a memorandum summarizing the Epstein investigation were withheld under attorney-client and deliberative process privileges.
Attorney Paul Cassell corresponded with U.S. Attorney Wifredo Ferrer in December 2010, prior to the formal recusal notices in 2011.
The document is a privilege log from a court filing, indicating litigation over the disclosure of internal DOJ communications related to the Epstein case.
